nCndEC2W2iEFctiTNL265g.text: There was a long queue when my friend and I decided to have dinner here. Instead of finding somewhere else to eat so we wouldn't have to wait so long, we decided to stick it out because where there's a crowd, there's usually treasure.After what seemed like 20 mins, a table was ready for us and, famished, we hurried in while tactfully eyeing the buffet spread and planning our attack. I spotted sushi, sashimi, fresh seafood, and grilled meat. With closer inspection I also noticed they had a spread of local & Italian dishes and  of course. desserts!  I was beyond ecstatic. I wouldn't say the ambiance was exceptional, unless of course you like the non-stop chattering of aunties, the occasional shrieks of laughter or screaming kids, but being there on a Sunday evening probably accounted for the rowdiness.Overall the experience was satisfying, and that's to say it was good food at value for money.

photos.caption: Photo of Buffet Town - Singapore, Singapore

ptPUbIpetOPX8Un-XDrDvw.text: I took my kids there and ended up with a horrible experience. Once of kids only ate bread. All the food was substandard. Will never attend a low cost place again. S$130+ was a waste.

lu8ijic5mTxUyln0R2tzqA.text: Through personal observations, I've noticed the general tendency among famished people to make poor dining decisions...and ever more so as the scale of desperation increases.Here was I definitely famished...and ending up making a poor decision when I spontaneously brought my fair lady to dine here for lunch. I am out of words as to how to really describe the experience but looking back, I have this weird wish that someone working the cashier collecting my $75+ for the both of us would have said something along the lines of "Welcome to Trailer Park Buffet, enjoy yer meal son."The food...selections looked wonderful as we traveled through the various sections deciding on which areas to begin our plunge. But experience teaches one that looks, however, are obviously deceiving (EDIT: I removed my original phrase here just in case I get seriously flamed; ask me via PM if you're curious).My initial attack started at the Teppanyaki-style section, which ironically ended up defining my expectations of the culinary standards of *trailer park buffet* for the rest of our meal - O-M-Freaking-BLAND. No salt. NO SALT. For goodness sake, WHY?Moving on, I dove straight into the fresh seafood section close to the entrance. The oysters...were shucked at the station continuously as the human bodies were never a scarcity when it comes to grabbing oysters. Fresh US oysters they say...well, they are partially correct. They did, however, forget to add "50% of the time". As for the others: mussels were as expected...tastes right out of the package; crawfish...dry; and scallops...really dry.Unsatisfied thus far, I entered a state of zombie frenzy and attacked the next meat section I came across (I skipped the "carving station" because they were serving HAM...ffs, HAM???) and grabbed as much satay skewers that my hand could get. Paired with peanut sauce, red onions, and cucumbers, I ate away not caring about the people behind me in the line that I must have juked in the process. Sorry people...I was late to the party and only have 15 minutes remaining in the dining experience...gotta play catch up.I moved on to the tempura section shortly after and grabbed about 15 prawns to my lady's horror (I'm allergic to shrimp in large amounts). While the prawns were decent, I held much love for the sweet potato tempura slices. LOVE, LOVE, LOVE.As the grand finale, I had two servings of salmon "sashimi" cut in front of me. (Side note: I wish one particular friend would see my facial expression right there and then...I was horrified by the knife skills and the method it was cut.) Anyways, the salmon tasted somewhat fresh...but wasn't deboned properly and still had the outer "unwanted" layer still present. (Oh well, it's a buffet...who expects knife skills and proper handling anyways...)All-in-all...a bad decision.*******I also worked most of the other sections by grabbing tidbits to determine if they were worth grabbing larger portions later on. Nothing stood out...didn't return for extra helpings./end-thy-whining/strongly-recommend-ala-skipYelp 100: 25/100

Photo of Buffet Town - Singapore, Singapore

tEQpUWtAf_Le8wFZNkW2-g.text: The value for money in this buffet place is incredibly low. Save your money, eat at another place. The prices are rather expensive, but what you get for the price is really not worth it.

4018D5iMLqfod87fh0m_qg.text: The quality of the food is decreasing. Though the chili crab stays consistent with its delicious taste. Though for a cheap buffet, its acceptable.

FEFBp1BcAPS02uq1FZqpxQ.text: This place is the worst!Came here because it was a work event and we needed to seat 30 people. Every single person said they would never come back. Every item from the rice to the meat and seafood was bland, tasteless and/or of poor quality. Even the deserts were gross.. the only item semi decent was the sashimi bar (that's probably why it's the first stand you see as you walk in to pay.I even waited 20 minutes to taste their chilli crab and when that came out it tasted like mini crab shells cooked in ketchup (and they were stingy with it.... you had to beg for some and wait only to realize it was not even worth eating)This is by far the worst food I've had in Singapore, one one of if not the worst buffet's anywhere. And to boot, they had the worst of all my pet peeves.. filthy bathrooms.AVOID!

1B-JUl5D0t_s2ys3LRjB_g.text: My friend and I visited yesterday for lunch.The young lady working at the entrance greeted us with "What do you want?" accompanied by a blank robotic expression.  That should have been our clue that cued us to walk away, but we paid $74.86 for 2 of us and entered into the steamy "Pit of Food"The restaurant was uncomfortably warm.   They had fans set up to try and make it better but it was not cool enough.  Most of the food was not bad, but not out of the ordinary. The Beef Randang was not good - tough, chewy and flavourless.  The freshly grilled beef and pork Satay were better.  The "budget" sushi and seafood selection was not impressive.  The fish was dry.  The desserts were mostly not good although I enjoyed the fried banana fritter.  The Good:  Strap on a bottomless feed sack and graze for hours for one price. ($37.43 each for Saturday lunch) The Bad:  The robotic receptionist, the uncomfortably warm restaurant, the low quality of some of the food and the queueing.  There was a long wait for the pork satay to cook because the kiasu guests in front would take 20-30 skewers at a time without any regard for those behind them. Loud and chaotic.  Noisy families with untamed children.  Did I mention the queueing?The Verdict:  If it is not your goal to consume endless quantities of mostly mediocre food in a loud chaotic environment - then shuffle away to one of the other restaurants in Raffles City. I would rather pay the same amount for better quality (and smaller portions) of food, better service and a calmer and more civilized atmosphere.  Not a good value.

kaCvPm-oR7uqEm5yomoulw.text: We came here because my hunny was hungry hungry. The presentation looked nice and the people were friendly.The food was okay. Tried my first Kopi C here and was not impressed at the quality compared to others I tried later.We left full, but rather had gone to a hawker center and tried many stalls for probably still half the price.

5pKYYuaF4wY5KYyd-cOdkg.text: I have a mixed feeling about Buffet Town. It's twice pricier than the better-quality buffets that I'm used to in the States. The place is really nice, the food is always freshly made, lots of variety undoubted, and presented nicely. I guess it's more of the location and service that I'm not a really fan of. It's always full and noisy, and the servers tend to rush you.

Qda6qTisiP9fKLJTalJklQ.text: Value for money, especially duting weekday lunches! Good spread of food, espcially local dishes such as chicken rice, satay, laksa, roti prata, tahu goreng, yong taufu, and rojak; they also serve sashimi, crayfish, ouster, prawns, teppanyaki and grilled fish head! Overall quality of food is alright! Get ready to fill your stomach with the spread!

hexKcSuFtDsJNdTbomsZxg.text: Lame town. Queue is long for everything. They take forever to refill the food. I.e the tempura prawn. While the refill the unwanted food. Lame indeed.

k-Igq141WGkTSjU48mNxbQ.text: The spread n food quality is not as good as my previous visit. They did not have any salmon sashimi.  The desert spread was limited. Like their location n spaciousness of the restaurant.

3gSnxsF_8obi96WxscK-aA.text: I want to give this place a 3.5 but I can't, so to be kind I am giving a 4.  There are a few things here that I realllly enjoy, and then a few things that I don't.  To my surprise, the seafood was actually quite good.  The sashimi is cut right in front of you, the shrimp and oysters taste fresh, and the chili crab was even worth a try.  I'm a big fan of chili crab and I have had my fair share.  The sauce is important to me, and for a buffet setting, I feel like the sauce from the chili crab was pretty good.  Better than this restaurant that I went to in Clarke Quay. There is a really nice variety, so this place is extremely good if you are with a group.  They have everything from meats, seafood - raw & cooked, local dishes like prata, chicken rice, and satay.  Try the satay for sure.  You will be pleasantly surprised :)  I've been here twice now, and will probably be back again in a couple months.
